In letters dated DATE and DATE , the applicant was informed of the assessment of his taxes ( NORP ) and of the supplementary tax due .

CARDINAL . NORP In its decision , ORG found that the applicant had intentionally not complied with the order of the tax authorities to provide information . However , according to LAW , persons liable to pay taxes were obliged to cooperate with the tax authorities , in particular to submit accounts , documents and other receipts in their possession which could be of relevance when determining the taxes . Moreover , the decision to impose supplementary taxes on the applicant had not acquired legal force as it had been withdrawn on CARDINAL and DATE by the President of ORG .
CARDINAL . The applicant filed an administrative - law appeal with ORG in which he complained , inter alia , LAW that as an accused he should not be obliged to incriminate himself .

CARDINAL . Meanwhile , the applicant also filed an objection against the third disciplinary fine , imposed on DATE and CARDINAL DATE , although the proceedings before the competent district court ( LOC ) were suspended pending the outcome of the proceedings before ORG .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG dismissed the applicant ’s administrative - law appeal , the decision being served on the applicant on DATE .

CARDINAL . In its decision , ORG considered it undisputed that the applicant had made investments with ORG and his companies which he , the applicant , had not declared . The tax authorities had not been in a position to assume that the means invested stemmed from income and assets which had already been taxed . They had therefore quite correctly asked the applicant to demonstrate the source of these moneys .

CARDINAL . ORG then recapitulated the relevant case - law . Tax - evasion proceedings constituted true criminal proceedings in respect of which the procedural guarantees , including those of LAW , applied . Thus , the offence of tax evasion led to a fine which had to be paid in addition to the taxes evaded . The fine constituted a sanction which had both preventive and repressive functions ; its amount was CARDINAL times the amount of the taxes evaded and it had the same effect for the person concerned as a criminal conviction .

CARDINAL . On the other hand , in ORG opinion the obligation to pay a supplementary tax did not amount to a criminal sanction . The supplementary tax was not separate in nature from the original tax debt ; rather , it was an additional tax resulting from an examination of the tax assessment of the person concerned and serving to bring in outstanding taxes . As such , it had no punitive function . The judgment continued :

“ even though the supplementary tax is not a criminal sanction within the meaning of LAW , the tax will be determined in tax - evasion proceedings in respect of which the guarantees of criminal procedure will apply . The question thus arises whether the person who has to pay taxes may be obliged , in the tax - evasion proceedings and with a view to the determination of the supplementary tax , to supply information on his financial circumstances . ”

CARDINAL . ORG then reiterated the principle of tax proceedings , according to which the burden of proof fell on the tax authorities to demonstrate that a person had not declared certain taxable income . It could not be said that the person concerned was obliged to incriminate himself . Rather , the person had merely to provide information as to the source of untaxed income which the tax authorities already knew existed . If in such a situation the person concerned had the right to remain silent , the entire tax system would be called into question . The regular tax - assessment proceedings would then have to be conducted according to the principles of criminal proceedings . The right to remain silent would complicate control , or even render it impossible . This could not be the purpose of LAW .

CARDINAL . According to ORG , there were a number of provisions in criminal law obliging a person to act in a particular way so as to enable the authorities to obtain his conviction . Reference was made in particular to lorries which had to be equipped with a tachograph recording speed and driving TIME . If there was an accident , the lorry driver was obliged to hand over the device . Similarly , a motorist might be obliged to submit to a blood or a urine test , and he would be punished if he refused to do so .

CARDINAL . ORG noted an essential difference from PERSON v. GPE ( judgment of DATE , Series A no . CARDINAL-A ) , namely , that in that case the tax authorities believed that certain documents existed although they were not certain of the fact . In the present case , the authorities were aware of the income which the applicant had invested . The purpose of their intervention was to ascertain whether this income itself stemmed from income or assets which had been duly taxed . All the applicant had to do was to explain the source of this income . In fact , he should have done so during the regular tax - assessment proceedings .

CARDINAL . Finally , ORG referred to ORG v. GPE , according to which presumptions of fact and law were compatible with LAW as long as they were confined within reasonable limits and the rights of the defence were maintained ( judgment of DATE , Series A no . TIME , pp . CARDINAL , § CARDINAL ) .
CARDINAL . ORG concluded that there was no breach of the applicant ’s right to the presumption of innocence or of his right not to incriminate himself .

CARDINAL . Supplementary - tax proceedings ( Nachsteuerverfahren ) serve the purpose of imposing a supplementary tax ( ORG ) where certain taxes have not been duly paid . Tax - evasion proceedings ( PERSON ) may lead , in addition to the supplementary tax , to a fine the amount of which will depend on the amount of the tax evaded .
